Subscribe Login e-Edition e-Edition News Trending: 🍔 Father's Day options ♻️ San Diego OKs trash fee 📚 Newest Barnes & Noble 🎡 2025 San Diego County Fair 🎶 State of music: 5 years after COVID **Council passes San Diego budget that restores library hours, fire rings and more — but at a cost to some city workers** **Mayor Todd Gloria said all the new spending makes him unsure if he'll sign it or try to make changes.** **Share this:** Click to share on X (Opens in new window)X Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Facebook Click to print (Opens in new window)Print Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)Email Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)Reddit The San Diego City Council approved a budget Tuesday that reversed the mayor’s proposed cuts to libraries, recreation centers and reservoir activities by boosting city revenues and eliminating several middle-management jobs. The council voted 7-2 for a compromise budget that also adds crucial funding forbrush managementto prevent wildfires, asafe parking lot for homeless familiesat the former Central Elementary and a backlog of neededflood channel clearing. The new $2.15 billion general fund budget, which covers the fiscal year that starts July 1, also restores money for many public restrooms in city parks anduses county money to restore funding for beach fire rings. The city’s independent budget analyst expressed concern about all the funding restorations and new spending, warning council members that many of the new revenues are uncertain and based on optimism. The analyst, Charles Modica, said the budget makes San Diego particularly vulnerable to an economic recession, which would shrink tax revenues and force immediate cuts or significantly deplete the city’s roughly $200 million in remaining reserves. Mayor Todd Gloria said Tuesday night that all the new spending and related moves by the council make him unsure whether he’ll sign the budget or try to make changes. The mayor can usehis line-item veto powerto eliminate new spending and make other changes. But the council can override such vetoes with votes from six members — one member fewer than approved the budget Tuesday. The primary sources of the new revenue, which total about $10 million, would be plans to startcharging for parking in Balboa Park and at the San Diego Zoosooner than expected, charging credit card fees at city parking meters and allowing digital billboards in the city. The budget restorations also rely on $2.7 million in cuts to management positions, including two communications officials and program coordinators and deputy directors in several other departments. The management cuts aggressively target the mayor’s office, including a confidential secretary position budgeted at $133,000 and two deputy chief operating officer jobs budgeted at $400,000 each in total pay. Deputy City Attorney Leslie Fitzgerald said it’s unclear whether the council has the power to be so precise about job cuts. “Under the city charter, the council has the authority to set the budget, including funding or defunding certain positions,” she said. “However, the charter does not give the council the authority to direct the mayor to fill positions or fire employees in those positions. That authority rests solely with the mayor.” Tuesday’s budget vote culminates months of debate and public protest prompted mostly by Gloria’s proposals to shut down all city libraries on Sundays and Mondays and to significantly reduce recreation center hours. The budget approved Tuesday leaves the Sunday library closures in place but restores Monday hours fully at 16 of the city’s 37 branches, many of them in low-income neighborhoods. The budget completely restores all proposed cuts to recreation centers. It also fully restores funding for boating and other activities at all city reservoirs, including Lake Murray and Lake Miramar. The main architects of the compromise budget — Councilmembers Henry Foster, Sean Elo-Rivera, Joe LaCava and Kent Lee — said at a Tuesday afternoon news conference the last-minute changes help prevent damage to low-income areas. “We’re restructuring management, responsibly generating revenue, and as a result we’re restoring parks, libraries and lakes,” Lee said. “These changes are targeted, tactical and tailored to help San Diego families who rely on the city the most.” Elo-Rivera said the efforts to boost revenue are crucial and timely. “This budget is not only responsible, but it meets the needs of our community at an incredibly trying time,” he said. “We are asking visitors to this city to chip in when they are visiting a treasure like Balboa Park, to no longer treat our city like a free playground. While we’re not restoring everything we’d like to restore, this is a giant step forward.” Councilmember Jennifer Campbell, who was joined in opposition by Councilmember Vivian Moreno, said she has major concerns about the reliability of the new revenues proposed Tuesday by her colleagues. “I am not convinced that entire list of things can be paid for in this particular budget,” Campbell said. “I don’t want us to get into a situation where we are spending much more than we have.” Moreno said she supports most of Tuesday’s changes but voted “no” because the budget doesn’t includeadequate money to plan future stormwater channel clearingto prevent floods. Modica, the budget analyst, expressed similar concerns to Campbell. “I’ve highlighted the potential risks associated with these revenues,” he said. “They may come to fruition. If they do not, I do want to be clear that we will be forced to tap into reserves or have cuts in the middle of the year.” Modica also talked about a possible recession. “This risk of an economic downturn, or even a full recession, is heightened,” he said. “There is very little buffer built into the budget to be able to absorb continued declines (in revenue).” Modicahas also expressed concernsabout budget projections he says are questionable, such as estimates that police and fire overtime pay will be $20 million lower in the new fiscal year than in the ongoing fiscal year. A spokesperson for the mayor, Rachel Laing, said in a news release that the mayor is also concerned about the budget the council adopted Tuesday. “The council added tens of millions of dollars in new spending and changes, many of which raised concerns from both the independent budget analyst and the City Attorney’s Office,” Laing said. The mayor has five days either to sign the budget or to issue line-item vetoes. “Over the next several days, the mayor and his team will closely review the council’s amendments to ensure the final budget meets the level of fiscal responsibility this moment demands, especially given the current economic uncertainty and global instability,” Laing said. The budget angst this spring is the result of San Diego facing itslargest projected deficit in more than a decade— a $258 million gap that increased to $350 million as revenues declined this spring. The deficit has been blamed on a series of pay raises totaling about 23% that were given to most employees in 2023 and to voters’ November rejection of a one-cent sales tax hike that would have raised $400 million a year. Gloria closed the gap with $100 million in cuts, with between $150 million and $200 million in new revenues from parking and other fees and by canceling $64 million in scheduled reserve contributions. The 16 library branches slated for full Monday service under the budget approved Tuesday are Allied Gardens, downtown, Carmel Valley, Logan Heights, Oak Park, City Heights, Rolando, Linda Vista, Mira Mesa, Point Loma, Rancho Bernardo, San Ysidro, Skyline, Valencia Park, North Park and University Heights. **Share this:** Click to share on X (Opens in new window)X Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Facebook Click to print (Opens in new window)Print Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)Email Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)Reddit **RevContent Feed** **Most Popular** Need a homeless shelter bed?
